transcript:
Patient: Thank you for your encouragement and support, Nova. It means a lot to hear that I'm making progress, even if it doesn't always feel that way.

Therapist: You're welcome, Amir. I want to acknowledge the hard work you've been putting in, even when it's challenging. It's not always easy to recognize our own progress, especially when we're struggling with depression and self-critical thoughts.

I'm curious, how do you feel about the idea of creating a personalized 'toolbox' of the CBT skills and strategies you've learned so far? We could include things like cognitive restructuring, compassionate self-talk, and any other tools that have been helpful for you.

Patient: I like that idea. Having a toolbox of skills to draw on could be really helpful, especially on days when I'm feeling particularly down or unmotivated. It would be good to have a reminder of the different techniques I can use to challenge those negative thoughts and feelings.

Therapist: Absolutely! A toolbox can be a great way to consolidate the skills you've learned and make them more accessible when you need them. We can work together to create a list of the tools that have been most helpful for you, along with some examples of how to use them in different situations.

Another important part of maintaining your progress is planning for potential setbacks or challenges. We call this relapse prevention planning. It involves identifying early warning signs that your depression symptoms might be worsening, and coming up with a plan for how to cope with those challenges using your CBT skills.

How do you feel about working together to create a relapse prevention plan for you?

Patient: That makes a lot of sense. I know that recovery isn't always a straight line, and there will probably be times when I struggle more than others. Having a plan in place for how to cope with those challenges could help me feel more prepared and less discouraged if and when they happen.

Therapist: You're absolutely right, Amir. Recovery is rarely a straight line, and having a plan in place can make a big difference in how we navigate those challenges when they arise.

Let's start by identifying some early warning signs that your depression symptoms might be worsening. These could be things like changes in your sleep or appetite, increased fatigue, or more frequent negative thoughts. What signs have you noticed in the past that might indicate your depression is getting worse?

Patient: Well, I know that when I start having trouble sleeping, that's often a sign that my depression is getting worse. I also tend to lose interest in things I usually enjoy, like singing or spending time with friends. And my negative thoughts tend to get louder and more persistent.

Therapist: Those are great examples of early warning signs, Amir. Changes in sleep, loss of interest in enjoyable activities, and increased negative thoughts are all common signs that depression symptoms might be worsening.

Now let's think about some strategies you could use to cope with those challenges if they arise. We can draw on the CBT skills you've already learned, as well as any other coping strategies that have been helpful for you in the past.

For example, if you notice that you're having trouble sleeping, you could try using some relaxation techniques before bed, like deep breathing or progressive muscle relaxation. If you're losing interest in enjoyable activities, you could try setting small, achievable goals for yourself, like singing one song a day or reaching out to a friend once a week.

What other coping strategies could you include in your relapse prevention plan?
